Thank you, David Lewis, Morgan Stanley, just a few quick ones here. Dominic, I felt today you made more specific comments on capital deployment, and maybe it signifies a change. But clearly you pulled back on share buybacks and you're increasing your investment in external investments through strategics, so some may infer from that J&J sees more opportunities outside the company than inside the company. Can you talk about why that would not be the case, and are there certain triggers that could cause you to reverse that process by deploying capital internally versus externally?

I don't think it's a particular sign either way. I think we have been very consistent over time, David, that we prefer organic growth first and we invest heavily in organic growth. We're pleased with the pipeline we have developed in Pharmaceuticals; and as Alex described today, the pipeline that's developing in medical devices as well. We supplement that always with external collaborations where we believe there is something that another entity has that we could take further than that entity has in its own hands. And finally, we overlay that with strategic acquisitions. I think the timing of that depends on what's available in the marketplace and what our view of the technology is. I don't want to give you any signal we changed our overall strategy on priority investing in organic growth first, supplemented with licensing and partnerships, and then add on strategic acquisitions where they make sense.

And Dominic, now that we have stabilization in the core business, specifically with generic headwinds beginning to ease, what have you seen so far for the first three quarters of 2009 that gives you the confidence that you can hold or fix the cost infrastructure so that we do see top line acceleration in '10? Are you going to see material leverage? Are there two or three things you could point to in terms of dynamics on fixing that cost infrastructure this year?

Sure. The one thing I would say is that the business overall and our business leaders like Alex and the folks that run the businesses actually are very in tune with creating cost structures that are sustainable over the long term. We don't typically cut cost. We typically restructure, rearrange our business, reconfigure the business to have sustainable cost structures. We have much more improvements now in technology infrastructure, which is becoming to be important leverage point for us going forward. You've heard me talk about all of our standardization efforts. They are actually gearing up, and we've employed the various shared service centers around the globe to allow us to then when we have more volume, to administer that volume at much less cost. I think all of those things combined give me confidence that we'll be able to maintain robust margins going forward.

Alex, maybe just one last quick question for you. As you think about the AF franchise, in the last 18 months it appears that Biosense has been maybe a net share loser as opposed to a gainer. Do you agree with that statement? Do you see increased economic pressure within Biosense, and what are implications for CARTO 3? Could that start becoming an accelerant for this business or the ability to gain share?

We think that the share actually has been pretty steady based upon all of our reports. And I think that any of the challenges that they have been experiencing have been more macroeconomic versus competitive. And we're actually quite excited about the CARTO 3 launch and the change and the improvement that it will offer both patients and physicians. We feel very confident and optimistic about that business.

There is one comment I would make really to pick up on one of Dominic's. I think that as he said, obviously we are all focused on being as cost conscious as we can be. But at the same time, I think it's important to note that we think it's really important to be able to invest in growth opportunities, as I discussed today. If you take a look at the for example clinical development program for NEVO, it's quite extensive. We're excited about the early data that we have on that product. When you combine it with the other additional studies that we plan to have at launch, when you look at the development program behind the Fibrin Pad, we think that that's truly one of a kind for a hemostat in the way it can change things; SEDASYS, the investment. So there are a lot of examples why we're managing in certain areas. We want to make sure that we can invest in other areas to produce the kind of long-term growth that we were describing.
Larry?

Thanks, Larry Biegelsen, Wells Fargo, two questions. First for Dominic, the full-year organic sales guidance implies an acceleration in the fourth quarter, if my math is correct, to about 4% on the low end, constant currency growth. First, is my math right and what's driving that? Are you expecting the Pharma and Consumer businesses to accelerate? That's my first question.

You're absolutely right. If you do the math, we should see a positive fourth quarter in terms of – even on a constant currency basis. There are two factors. There are some launches that we've talked about that are now going to obviously see much more acceleration in the fourth quarter than we're currently seeing because they have just been recently launched. We talked earlier last year; we have a 53-week year. So this fourth quarter will actually have actually more days of sales than we had in the third quarter, so that will add to the operational growth. And that has been included in the guidance we've been giving all year.

On the med tech fee or tax, is there any chance you see that being pushed out to 2013 when you can get the volume offset? And second, if it's reduced, let's say, in half to 2 billion a year, what is your ability to offset that? Thanks.

I'll ask Alex also to comment. I think, obviously, we're hopeful it will be reduced. I think that the unusual part of the legislation is that the costs that are being asked of the industry to contribute are not offset by increased patient volumes until much later, right? So, we've obviously had lots of dialogue about that with the administration. I think both are valid points that we've raised. It's not our expectation, though, that it will be delayed. Our expectation is that it will be at whatever appropriate level is eventually enacted, it will be enacted in the near term. Alex, do you agree with that?

I completely agree with Dominic's comments. I think we're working hard right now with and others to make sure that we really explain what could potentially be unintended consequences from some aspects of the pending legislation. In just the areas that you mentioned, as far as the timing, as far as what's included, what's not included, I still think there are some moving pieces, and we'll see how it all comes together. But, we're hopeful that we can make some additional headway there.

And in terms of offsetting that, I think similar to the comment that Catherine raised and I'll have to answer it the same way, which is we're going through the process now. It would be premature for us to comment. We want to focus our attention on getting it right with the administration first. And then we'll take the appropriate steps and we'll obviously advise you of that when we're ready to do it so.
Thank you. With respect for everyone's time, we'll take two more questions. Bruce?

Good morning, it's Erik Schneider for Bruce Nudell from UBS. First on ASPs in ortho, you described your view going forward as conservative with respect to pure price. I Do you still expect that the mix benefits in the U.S. and/or outside the U.S. will offset those price pressures? Do you expect it to stay even? Do you expect it to be a benefit just forward-looking, and also your expectations for sustainable worldwide unit growth in major ?

Erik, what I would say is that in terms of mix, we do think that there will be an opportunity for a positive impact of mix, but we do think that the technology and the innovation required to demonstrate that positive mix is going to be increasingly challenging. So we see a net positive from mix. Whether it will offset the entire price is yet to be determined. We'll have to see how pricing evolves. But from what we're seeing now, if we continue to offer improvements in whether it's knees, hips, spine, other areas, there can be an offset in mix that we're seeing in at least the recent quarters and we would project that going forward.

Regarding overall unit volume, it's difficult to say, but if we look at this past year, we do think that the macroeconomic issues have had an impact and that can range from people not wanting to step out of their job or workplace and be out of work for an extended period of time. It can be over concern over insurance coverage. And outside the United States, it can actually be the result of increasing queues as governments try to tighten their budgets and rein in some of their healthcare spending.

We don't think fundamentally that the unmet medical need, the need for knees and hips has changed. And so, we do think that it will return to somewhat of a more normal state once we get through this current economic period, but that's a projection on our part. But, we don't see any other factors that would suggest that the underlying rate of replacement for those types of procedures would change.

And then Louise or Dominic, with respect to XARELTO, which I think you expect to file in the fourth quarter, are you waiting for the Einstein-Extension data for that or are you comfortable before seeing that with the bleeding profile of the product?
The Einstein-Extension data will be shared at at the end of the year, but it's not contingent on us completing the response.
Thank you.
Tao, are you back here?

Thank you, it's Tao Levy from Deutsche Bank. I just want to be clear on the inventory stocking and impact from healthcare reform. Do you see any changes in the quarter on hospital behavior specifically in the third quarter?
We haven't seen noticeable changes at that level.
Okay, great, and also PCI volumes were very challenged this quarter. Is there anything that happened here in the third quarter in the overall markets?

It was down 2% in second quarter. Louise talked about down 6 or 7% this quarter. That's compared to about a 4% rate I believe, growth rate in prior quarters. Again, we believe it's due to the more macroeconomic conditions. There could be some anomalies compared to year to year comparisons because of data releases in previous years. That is our best thinking at this point.
Thanks.
Thanks, we'll have some final comments from Dominic.

Thanks, Louise, and thank you, Alex, for a terrific review of MD&D portfolio. Let me just offer these final thoughts. We continue to invest in our broad base of healthcare businesses with a long-term view, and we focus on innovation and continue to make progress in bringing our pipeline of products to the market.

We recognize these are challenging factors today and the environment remains challenging, but we remain financially strong, disciplined, and focused when developing and executing plans that will keep us well positioned for long-term growth. I'm confident in our ability to innovate and execute on the growth opportunities we see thanks to the dedication and focus of the talented people across the Johnson & Johnson family of companies. I look forward to updating you on our full-year 2009 results when we meet with you in January. Thanks very much and have a great day.
